name: Orunmila
description: Yoruba deity of wisdom, knowledge, and prophecy. Known as the deity of divination and the keeper of the secrets of Ifa.
mythology: Orunmila was present at the creation of humanity and knows the destiny of all human beings. He teaches through the Ifa divination system.
stories: The creation of the Ifa divination system
Teaching humanity the secrets of destiny
His role in the pantheon of Orishas
worship: Consulted through Ifa divination, offerings of palm oil, kola nuts, and prayers. Babalawo priests serve as intermediaries.
significance: Central to Yoruba spirituality, provides guidance and wisdom to believers. The Ifa corpus is considered a repository of Yoruba knowledge.
family: Son of Olodumare (Supreme God), brother to other Orishas

name: Isis
description: Ancient Egyptian goddess of magic, motherhood, healing, and rebirth. One of the most important deities in the Egyptian pantheon.
mythology: Wife of Osiris and mother of Horus. After Osiris was killed by Set, Isis used her magic to resurrect him and conceive Horus.
stories: The birth and protection of Horus
Her search for the scattered pieces of Osiris
worship: Temples throughout Egypt, festivals celebrating her mysteries, offerings of bread, beer, and flowers.
significance: Embodied the ideal of motherhood and wifely devotion. Her cult spread throughout the Roman Empire.
family: Wife of Osiris, mother of Horus, sister of Nephthys and Set

name: Anansi
description: West African trickster god often depicted as a spider. Known for his wisdom, cunning, and role as a cultural hero.
mythology: Anansi often acts as a bridge between the human and divine worlds, bringing knowledge and stories to humanity through his cleverness.
stories: How Anansi scattered wisdom across the world
Anansi and the pot of wisdom
Various trickster tales teaching moral lessons
worship: Honored through storytelling, particularly during evening gatherings. Stories serve as both entertainment and moral instruction.
significance: Preserves oral tradition and cultural values through stories. Represents the power of wit over strength.
family: Often portrayed with wife Aso and sons, part of Akan spiritual tradition

name: Shango
description: Yoruba deity of thunder, lightning, fire, and drums. Former king of the Oyo Empire who was deified after his death.
mythology: Originally a powerful king of Oyo, Shango became an Orisha after his death. He controls thunder and lightning and is known for his fiery temperament.
domain: Thunder, Lightning, Fire, Justice, Dance, Virility
stories: His reign as king of Oyo
worship: Dance ceremonies with bata drums, offerings of red palm oil, red foods, and prayers for justice and protection.
significance: Represents divine justice and royal power. His worship spread throughout the African diaspora.
family: Husband to Oya, Oshun, and Oba. Son of Yemoja and Oranyan
